Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Enforcement of cooperation in vampire bats
Award.AbstractNarration: Social cooperation can be exploited and eroded by freeloading, which occurs when some individuals receive help from others at no expense to themselves. Natural selection is expected to favor social organisms that cooperate in ways that prevent such freeloading. Most commonly, altruistic traits become protected from freeloading and self-perpetuating because they help relatives, who also inherit and pass along those same altruistic traits. For cooperation between non-relatives, organisms can potentially prevent freeloading by increasing investment in partnerships that yield returns while decreasing investment in partnerships that are less beneficial. This project uses food sharing in common vampire bats as a model cooperation system to test if and how freeloading is prevented. Female vampire bats will voluntarily regurgitate portions of their own meals to feed hungry roost-mates. This seemingly altruistic behavior occurs among related and nonrelated individuals, is inducible, and is measurable under controlled settings without training. Bats will accept and reject food-sharing partners within a group, which provides a way to test the effects of genetic similarity, familiarity, and reciprocity on cooperative decisions. Through a series of experiments on captive animals this project will address three questions about how vampire bats enforce social cooperation. First, can vampire bats discriminate kin from non-kin using vocalizations? Second, will vampire bats exert social partner choice by preferentially helping partners that reciprocated more than others? Third, in the absence of partner choice, will vampire bats exert social partner control by reducing investments in partners that reciprocate less over time? The project will train undergraduate and graduate students and support several outreach activities, including presentations at academic and public forums. Studying the mechanisms underlying cooperation in nonhuman animals has potential to provide new insight into the origins of human social behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of cooperation creates a puzzle because cooperative behaviors can be exploited by freeloading strategies resulting in the breakdown of cooperation. This evolutionary tragedy of the commons can be prevented by several conditions (such as limited dispersal, repeated interactions, and partner choice) or enforced by several strategies (kin discrimination, reciprocity, punishment). However, cooperative and exploitative strategies coevolve over time. As cooperative traits improve, new strategies for exploiting them are favored. As a consequence, we might expect that social decisions will integrate different kinds of social information. Identifying what these strategies are, and how they work can provide insight into general principles of social cooperation.

Our understanding of how cooperative relationships are maintained has relied on several experimental systems including cleaning behaviors in fish, cooperative breeding in birds and mammals, and allogrooming in primates. The goal of this project was to use food-sharing in common vampire bats as an alternative model for determining how cooperation is enforced (Figure 1).

Female vampire bats appear to possess long-term cooperative social bonds analogous to human friendships. Vampire bats drink nothing but blood, they can starve to death after missing just 2-3 nights of failed foraging, and they typically obtain either a large blood meal or none at all. When a hungry female bat comes back to the roost in need of food, roost mates will typically regurgitate a portion of their own ingested food to feed her (Figure 2). Food sharing occurs between both kin and non-kin adults. Food-sharing networks are stable over time, reciprocal, and correlated with mutual grooming. This natural cooperative behavior is special because it is inducible and measurable under controlled settings without training, allowing us to test the relative importance of genetic similarity, familiarity, and reciprocity. We previously showed that, for familiar bats, social experiences, such as reciprocal sharing and grooming, were more important than kinship for explaining food donation rates. This indicates that reciprocity overshadows kin altruism.

The project has provided several new insights into how vampire bats enforce social cooperation. By experimentally preventing donations in seven bonded dyads (14 females), we found that bats that fed more non-kin in previous years coped better with the absence of a primary kin donor: they had more donors and received more food. This finding shows that non-kin cooperation can provide ‘backup’ donors for when close kin are unavailable. That is, non-kin donations expand a bat’s network of potential donors (Figure 3).

We also found that—when sharing in targeted dyads was prevented on 3 occasions over 3 weeks and then permitted again—the result was an increased variance in donation contributions. Five donation rates decreased to zero, but six increased to near 100% of the subject’s total food received. This pattern is consistent with alternative strategies for responding to non-reciprocation. 
Using playback trials, we found that vampire bats are attracted to contact calls based more on past sharing than kinship of the caller. Isolated vampire bats approached sooner and spent longer near a speaker playing contact calls of high donors compared to a speaker playing contact calls of low donors. However, we failed to find evidence that bats were in general attracted to calls from kin compared to non-kin. The exception was that mothers were more attracted to calls of their grown offspring than to calls from a control bat. 

We showed that inhaled oxytocin slightly increased the magnitude of food donations within dyads, and the amount of female allogrooming within and across all partners, without increasing number of partners. ...
